importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Chen Ning Yang was born in 1922 in Anhui province, China, marking the beginning of a life that would profoundly influence theoretical physics and global scientific understanding.
Yang received his science degree from National Southwest Associated University in 1942, a pivotal moment in his early academic development during wartime China.

In 1957, Yang and Lee Tsung-Dao won the Nobel Prize in Physics for their work on parity violation, a breakthrough that reshaped particle physics and established new foundational principles in quantum theory.
Yang was awarded an honorary doctorate by Princeton University in 1958, recognizing his exceptional contributions to theoretical physics and global scientific education.
The death of Yang's first wife, Chih Li Tu, in 2003 marked a personal turning point, leading to his later marriage to Weng Fan and influencing public perception of his personal life and resilience.
Yang and Weng Fan reconnected in 2004, a significant personal event that highlighted the human dimension of a scientific icon and inspired narratives about age, love, and personal fulfillment.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from Yang's birth in 1922 to his Nobel Prize win in 1957 represents a defining era in modern physics, during which breakthroughs in symmetry and particle theory transformed scientific understanding.
The early 1950s to early 1960s saw Yang's rise as a leading theoretical physicist, with recognition including the Nobel Prize and honorary doctorates, establishing him as a global scientific figure.
The period from 2003 to 2025 includes Yang's later life, marked by personal transformation and public attention following his death at age 103, reflecting on legacy and human resilience.

keyTakeAways: Chen Ning Yang was a Chinese physicist who won the 1957 Nobel Prize in Physics with Lee Tsung-Dao for their discovery of parity violation in weak nuclear interactions.
Yang's work on symmetry principles and statistical mechanics has had a lasting impact on modern physics, influencing theories about elementary particles and the fundamental forces of nature.
A professor at Tsinghua University and honorary dean at the Institute for Advanced Study, Yang played a key role in shaping scientific education in China and beyond.

Born in 1922 in Anhui province, Yang began his academic journey at Tsinghua University, where his father was a mathematics professor, and later studied at the University of Chicago under Enrico Fermi.
He received the Albert Einstein Commemorative Award in 1957 and an honorary doctorate from Princeton University in 1958, underscoring international recognition of his scientific contributions.
Yang married Chih Li Tu in 1950, who died in 2003; he later married Weng Fan, a student he met in 1995, which drew global attention to his personal life and emotional depth.
Yang died at the age of 103 in 2025, making him one of the longest-lived Nobel laureates and a symbol of enduring intellectual and personal legacy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Chen Ning Yang, a Chinese Nobel laureate in Physics, has died at the age of 103, according to Chinese state media. Awarded the 1957 Nobel Prize in Physics alongside Lee Tsung-Dao for their groundbreaking work on parity violation in particle physics, Yang made significant contributions to theoretical physics, particularly in symmetry principles and statistical mechanics. Born in 1922 in Anhui province, he studied at National Southwest Associated University and later at the University of Chicago under Enrico Fermi, where he developed a deep scientific foundation. He served as a professor at Tsinghua University and as an honorary dean at the Institute for Advanced Study. Yang received international recognition including the Albert Einstein Commemorative Award and an honorary doctorate from Princeton University. After the death of his first wife in 2003, he married Weng Fan, a student he met in 1995, which drew global attention to his personal life and emotional resilience. His death at 103 makes him one of the longest-lived Nobel laureates and underscores both his scientific legacy and the human story behind a life of intellectual achievement.
